awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Granular Power Electronics at the Grid Edge
awd_abstract_narration:
Power electronics are the key building blocks of future energy systems. Power electronics play critical roles in renewable energy integration, computing and telecommunication, grid-scale energy storage, and transportation electrification, all at the edge of the future smart grid. These emerging energy systems are usually modular and granular. This research project targets a generalized design method that will enable a new family of power electronics that can achieve high performance and perform new functions at the grid edge for a variety of applications. ``Granular power electronics'' represents a systematic design approach that pushes the intelligence and capability of power electronics to a granular level that has not been demonstrated before. The PI will leverage the recent advances in wide-band-gap devices, circuit architectures, and control methodologies to address the challenges of controlling sophisticated power flow, modeling magnetics with granular structures, and addressing the inverter-to-inverter oscillation problem in nano-grids with many smart inverters. The results of this project will be incorporated into the efforts that the PI is currently leading as a part of the "Campus-as-a-Lab" program to create research opportunities for undergraduate students. The outreach program for K-12 students, involving them in the development of experimental demos, will expose them to the role of power electronics in improving the quality and sustainability of our daily lives and attract them to pursue STEM careers.

The PI will perform a systematic investigation on the fundamental principles of granular and modular power electronics. The PI will (1) develop design toolkits (modules, schematics, and layout patterns) comprising switched-inductor cells, switched-capacitor cells, bridge structures, and magnetic-couplers which may serve as the basis of granular power conversion architectures, (2) establish systematic methods to evaluate the topology, select the components, control the power flow, model the magnetics, estimate the grid impedance, and perform stability analysis of granular power electronics and systems with sophisticated power flow; (3) develop open-source computer-aided-design tools for the design and control of granular power conversion architectures; and (4) build small-scale experimental systems to verify the developed methods and benefit education. The PI will use three emerging and important energy systems at the grid edge as examples - smart inverters (distributed energy generation), large scale energy systems (data center power delivery), and a nano-grid test platform for multidisciplinary energy systems research. High performance grid-interface power electronics topologies will be studied, and model-based multi-agent control strategies will be developed to enable a future smart grid with many granular power electronics at the edge.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

The core intellectual merit of this project includes the following fundamental understandings of power electronics, which leads to a wide range of innovations in each thrust of the project:

  • Modular, scalable, distributed, and granular power electronics systems
  • High-frequency hybrid-switched-capacitor-magnetics architecture
  • Modeling and design of high-performance power magnetics

These fundamental understandings were then applied to the three thrusts listed in the CAREER proposal to demonstrate the impact of granular power electronics at the grid edge:

  • Thrust 1: Granular Power Electronics for Grid Interface
  • Thrust 2: Granular Power Electronics for Power Management
  • Thrust 3: A Nano-Grid Test Platform for Multidisciplinary Grid Research

Outcome 1: 2x IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics Prize Paper Awards:

  • Y. Chen et al., “Multicell Reconfigurable Multi-Input Multi-Output Energy Router Architecture,” IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics, 2020. [Second Place Prize Paper]
  • P. Wang, et al., “Differential Power Processing for Ultra-Efficient Data Storage,” IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics, 2021. [Second Place Prize Paper]

Outcome 2: Multidisciplinary research impact with power systems and data science

  • Y. Wu, et al., “Impedance Profile Prediction for Grid-Connected VSCs with Data-Driven Feature Extraction,” IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics, 2025.
  • Y. Li, et al., “Machine Learning at the Grid-Edge: Data-Driven Impedance Models for Model-Free Smart Inverters,” IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics, 2024.
  • Y. Liao, Y. Li, M. Chen, L. Nordström, X. Wang, P. Mittal, and H. V. Poor, “Neural Network Design for Impedance Modeling of Power Electronic Systems Based on Latent Features,” IEEE Trans. on Neural Networks and Learning Systems, 2024.

Outcome 3: Industry collaborations on power electronics at the grid edge

  • M. Liao et al., “UAV Fleet Charging on Telecom Towers with Differential Capacitive Wireless Power Transfer,” IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics, accepted.
  • M. Liao, et al., “Machine Learning Methods for Feed-forward Power Flow Control of Multi-Active-Bridge Converters,” IEEE Trans. on Power Electronics, 2023.

 

Broader Impact:

Magnet Challenge and International Impact

The NSF CAREER support enabled my group to dive deep into machine learning methods for power magnetics modeling. Since 2018, my group has launched and is leading the MagNet project - currently the world’s largest and highest quality open-source power magnetics database as a platform to advance research on power magnetics and power electronics design. The 2023 IEEE PELS-Google-Enphase-Princeton MagNet Challenge attracted 40 student teams from 18 countries with 200+ student participants (including female students, underrepresented minorities, and under-developed countries around the world), with core results published at:

  • M. Chen et al., "MagNet Challenge for Data-Driven Power Magnetics Modeling," in IEEE Open Journal of Power Electronics, 2025.

Undergraduate and High School Research Opportunities

The NSF CAREER support enabled my group to continuously offer independent research and summer internship opportunities to undergraduate and high school students. One critical topic that has gained momentum in my group is sustainable power electronics. With the wide spread of granular power electronics at the grid edge, it is important to consider the sustainability of power electronics systems and factor this into the overall system optimization. Example undergraduate thesis topics include:

  • Camille Sevrain - Power Electronics Considerations for Sustainable EV Charging
  • Sekinat Aliu - Designing for Advanced Environmental Analysis: Utilizing Single-Stage CNNs and AutoML for Enhanced Component Identification and Electronic Life-Cycle Assessment
  • Thomas Atwood - Design of a Solid-State Transformer in Pursuit of more Sustainable Power Electronics Solutions

Graduate student Mian Liao was also selected as the winner of the New Jersey Economic Development Authority Wind Institute Fellowship for a proposal on grid interface power electronics.

Figure Explanations:

  • Figure 1: Overview of Princeton research portfolio on granular power electronics.
  • Figure 2: Key principles of granular power conversion and advanced magnetics design.
  • Figure 3: Prototypes of granular power electronics at the grid edge for power management.
  • Figure 4: Grid edge power architecture and industry collaborations.
  • Figure 5: International participants of the MagNet Challenge in 2023.
  • Figure 6: Synergetic activities for education, outreach and work force training.

Intellectual Merit:


The core intellectual merit of this project includes the following fundamental understandings of power electronics, which leads to a wide range of innovations in each thrust of the project:

Modular, scalable, distributed, and granular power electronics systems
High-frequency hybrid-switched-capacitor-magnetics architecture
Modeling and design of high-performance power magnetics



These fundamental understandings were then applied to the three thrusts listed in the CAREER proposal to demonstrate the impact of granular power electronics at the grid edge:

Thrust 1: Granular Power Electronics for Grid Interface

Thrust 3: A Nano-Grid Test Platform for Multidisciplinary Grid Research

Broader Impact:


Magnet Challenge and International Impact


The NSF CAREER support enabled my group to dive deep into machine learning methods for power magnetics modeling. Since 2018, my group has launched and is leading the MagNet project - currently the worlds largest and highest quality open-source power magnetics database as a platform to advance research on power magnetics and power electronics design. The 2023 IEEE PELS-Google-Enphase-Princeton MagNet Challenge attracted 40 student teams from 18 countries with 200+ student participants (including female students, underrepresented minorities, and under-developed countries around the world), with core results published at:

M. Chen et al., "MagNet Challenge for Data-Driven Power Magnetics Modeling," in IEEE Open Journal of Power Electronics, 2025. 



Undergraduate and High School Research Opportunities


The NSF CAREER support enabled my group to continuously offer independent research and summer internship opportunities to undergraduate and high school students. One critical topic that has gained momentum in my group is sustainable power electronics. With the wide spread of granular power electronics at the grid edge, it is important to consider the sustainability of power electronics systems and factor this into the overall system optimization. Example undergraduate thesis topics include:

Camille Sevrain -Power Electronics Considerations for Sustainable EV Charging
Sekinat Aliu - Designing for Advanced Environmental Analysis: Utilizing Single-Stage CNNs and AutoML for Enhanced Component Identification and Electronic Life-Cycle Assessment

Graduate student Mian Liao was also selected as the winner of the New Jersey Economic Development Authority Wind Institute Fellowship for a proposal on grid interface power electronics.
